Description/Use Case: TCP Connect Scan: Standard full handshake scan (Large Window)
SYN Scan: Stealth half-open scan signature (Small Window)
UDP Scan Response: Port Unreachable (Confirms UDP scan on closed port)
ICMP Tunneling: Detects payloads larger than standard Ping (Windows=32b, Linux=48b).
Host Discovery: ARP broadcast to identify live hosts
ARP Poisoning: Duplicate IP detected (Potential MitM)
ARP Flood: High volume of requests (Check Statistics)
Success: Successful HTTP requests (200 OK)
Dir Busting: High volume indicates directory bruteforce/scanning
Access Denied: Attempts to access restricted resources
Data Upload: Potential Webshell interaction, logon attempts or data exfiltration
File Upload: Potential WebDAV malicious file upload
Resource Removal: Attempt to delete files/logs via API or WebDAV

Filter Syntax (Wireshark): http.user_agent contains "sqlmap" || http.user_agent contains "Nmap" || http.user_agent contains "Nikto"
Description/Use Case: Hack Tool: Default User-Agent from automated scanners

Filter Syntax (Wireshark): (ip contains "jndi") or ( ip contains "Exploit") or (frame contains "jndi") or ( frame contains "Exploit") or (http.user_agent contains "$") or (http.user_agent contains "==")
Description/Use Case: Exploit: JNDI injection attempt (CVE-2021-44228)
Client Hello: Identify initiation of secure connections. Source of SNI and JA3 data.
Account Context: Identifies target username. Critical for attribution.
Credential Context: Captures cleartext password. Confirms if credential was leaked.
Brute Force: Login failed (Sequence of 530s)
Login Success: Successful authentication
File Enumeration: Check files in current directory
Movement: Change Working Directory. Tracks attacker's lateral movement path.
Verification: Print Working Directory. Attacker confirming current location.
Download: Attacker retrieved a file
Upload: Attacker uploaded a file
SMB File Transfer: Detect NT Create AndX (File creation/opening)
Beaconing Analysis: Filter queries to calculate frequency (Jitter/Interval)
Long Subdomains: Detects data exfiltration encoded in long subdomains (Tunneling).
TXT Record C2: Detects TXT records often used to carry C2 payloads (Base64).
Fast Flux: High number of IP resolutions returned for a single domain.
Nuclear Search: Search ENTIRE packet (Headers Body Hex) for a string. Best for initial blind hunting.,High noise if keyword is common (e.g. "com").
Case-Insensitive Hunt: Regex search ignoring case (e.g. finds 'Admin' 'admin' 'ADMIN'). Crucial for evasion detection.,Computationally expensive on large PCAPs.
Path Hunting: Search specifically in file paths/directories (e.g. .bak .config private)
Parameter Hunting: Search full URL including GET parameters (e.g. finds SQLi payloads)
Content Hunting: Search ONLY in the response body (HTML/JSON). Good for finding defacement.
Infrastructure Hunt: Search for suspicious domain patterns in Host headers.
Post Body Hunt: Search inside POST requests (e.g. login passwords webshell content)
Hostname Extraction: Identify the machine name (Hostname) from DHCP Request packets.
OS Fingerprinting: Analyze "Parameter Request List" to infer OS type (Windows requests distinct params vs Linux).
NetBIOS Name: Identify Windows Hostnames and Workgroups on local subnet.
Windows Build ID: SMB Session Setup often reveals the exact Native OS and Kernel Build version.
SNI Hunt: Search the intended domain name in cleartext even if traffic is encrypted.
Weak Encryption: Detect usage of weak ciphers often used by legacy malware or C2.
Cert Analysis: Hunt for suspicious Certificate Subject names (e.g. self-signed fake company names).
Cert Issuer: Identify free/automated SSL providers commonly abused by Phishing/C2.
Protocol Version: Detect legacy TLS 1.0 traffic. Indicates outdated systems or malware beacons.
Fatal Alert: Detect failed handshakes. High volume indicates SSL Scanning.
